title: Not able to deploy contract on network
body:
## Issue

I have developed a Quorum maker network and configured the truffle-config.js to connect to it. If I open truffle console, it makes no errors, so I understand is accessing the network. Also, I am able to acces web UI of quorum maker so in fact the network is created. 

However, when I tried to deploy a contract through truffle, I got: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21060405/57374519-746c2b80-7171-11e9-843f-e4825474acc1.png)

Also, if I deploy the contract directly from quorum maker web UI, the contracts appears to be deployed but if form truffle console I run "networks", I get that no contract is deployed on the network, so something is generating that inconsistency and I don't understand the reason. 

## Steps to Reproduce
Create Quorum maker network on centOS virtual Machine with IP 192.168.26.9 and RPC port 22000
Join node on same IP but different ports
configure truffle-config.js to work with that network
Compile contracts
Try to deploy

## Expected Behavior

Get my contract deployed and accessible over truffle console and stop getting inconsistencies with quorum maker

## Actual Results
 This error got displayed: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21060405/57375040-bf3a7300-7172-11e9-8b92-fb706023e2e6.png)

And truffle console shows (the first output is about ganache, the second one is the one of Quorum Maker)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21060405/57375075-de390500-7172-11e9-962d-79712d24f0e8.png)

## Environment

* Operating System: CentOS 7
* Ethereum client: Geth - Quorum Maker network 
* Truffle version (`truffle version`):  v5.0.14
* node version (`node --version`): v10.15.1
* npm version (`npm --version`): 6.4.1
Can you show us your truffle config? It sounds like something might be up with your provider possibly if you're getting authentication errors?

I commented the lines of "from" and "websockets" because when I include "websockets=true" I only got "connection not open send()"
I am able to open truffle console on development, which makes me think it is identifying some network, but I ran "web3.eth.isSyncing()" and got false. I also got false on "web3.eth.isMining()" . Also, on "web3.eth.defaultAccoun" I got null eventhough I set the "from" field on truffle-config.js
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21060405/57465255-98ed0400-7254-11e9-9f45-f876e1470340.png)

Also when I ran the command to get the provider, I got 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21060405/57465397-e9646180-7254-11e9-8373-8939899291b3.png)
Hmm yeah it seems like there is something wrong with the way you are connecting. I'll talk to some of my team that are more familiar with quorum.

But that error you are getting, "authentication needed: password or unlock" is not from Truffle. Or actually you probably need to unlock some accounts on starting Geth so that they can be used. It would make sense that you could connect to it and do some basic things but not send transactions.

I tried to get around that error by setting "from" on deployer with one of the 2 addresses. I put the one I was able to unlock which happens to be the one with balance. 
The other account, which is coinbase, was impossible to unlock. It asks for a passphrase, which is supposed  to be an empty string but introducing an empty string fails.

I managed to unlock one account and I reach this point: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21060405/57544271-47fd0e80-732d-11e9-8357-5114a962f1b3.png)

It seems that migrations contract got deployed, and actually on quorum maker web UI it appears that one contract was deployed. But I do not understand why it keeps asking for authentication.

Also I do not understand why can the quorum maker web UI showing that there is a contract that got deployed, but is not shown on truffle console. Also, even though the contract is deployed, the ABI is not upload. On Quorum wiki it says that a symlink needs to be created, but from where to where?

You might try unlocking the accounts on the Geth side of things. In the past I have always created the accounts and unlocked them as part of the startup command. Perhaps it is different with Quorum...I'll ask my colleague who has more Quorum experience.

Well, like the message says, the network state is unknown so maybe one of the transactions was completely successful and then failed for some other reason. I'm not sure :)

I believe that the first reason of failure is the first error of authentication. 

Have you been able to ask your colleague? Or do you have any idea on the question about the symlink or reason for the inconsistency between truffle and Quorum maker?

Hey @romisalve ! I suspect there's some kind of miscommunication happening between Quorum Maker and Truffle. Will need some time to explore Q Maker under the hood, but I have a hunch that unlike the Quorum 7nodes example (https://github.com/jpmorganchase/quorum-examples/tree/master/examples/7nodes), Q Maker doesn't handle minting of new blocks. It _looks_ like Q Maker confirms tx receipt, but that the pending block is never minted.

If you have more insight into how Q Maker handles block validation, would love to hear about it 🙏

@romisalve , following up on this. There are a couple of things going on.

1) websockets definitely aren't working w/ Quorum, but I'm not sure if it's something that needs to be enabled on the Quorum Maker side, or if it's the version of `web3.js` we're using that is unable to converse with Q Maker using websockets. 
1) Since Quorum is a permissioned chain, we can expect standard `web3.js` methods like `web3.eth.isSyncing` & `web3.eth.isMining` to return false (no mining, only validating). Also, the web3 lib we're currently using (`web3.js`) [especially versions >1.0] is very EVM-specific.
1) There appears to be a default timeout occurring on the Q Maker side of things. If I `migrate` and `migrate --reset` a bunch within roughly 5 mins of joining/creating a Q Maker network, everything works as expected. There _could_ be something we're not handling on our side of things. Will need to verify by modifying some of the Q Maker geth node start-up scripts.

Actually I have not changed anything on my configuration and now is deploying. The only thing I have to do is unlock the node account. 
Well, I also had to split my contract in smaller ones because it said that the contract could not be store, but once I split it, I was able to deploy to the network and from truffle console, it shows that a contract is deployed. 
Anyway, on quorum maker web UI there are no ABI for the contracts. 
Do I need to have the ABI accesible through quorum maker web UI or it is not necessary and I can work directly with truffle if I want to develop  a dApp?

No, I was not able to unlock it perpetually, but web3.personal.unlockAccount("address", "pass", 0); unlocks it until geth client is shut down. 

I can share my contract of course, can I paste it here or how do you want me to share it? I don´t understand de reason of that error. 

Now I tried to split it into smaller contracts and I am getting this error when trying to call a function but I don´t understand what is happening on my contract 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21060405/57934808-d4ac4d00-7896-11e9-9168-7bd06ee73e6f.png)

Can you share a repo link to your truffle project? Would make it easier for reproduction and debugging.

Where & when are you making the `web3.personal.unlockAccount` call?

https://github.com/romisalve/Quorum-POC.git There is my contract. There are a lot of commented lines due to the following reasons :

When I tried to compile it I got "stack too deep error" and started commentig lines of returns (of course it was not the most intelligent decision but I didn´t how to solve it)
I have a lot of internal functions which actually I believe I need them as public because as internal they can only be called inside the contract or I am wrong? But if I put them as public, I end on the same error of "can´t store.." 

Now I was trying through truffle console (from where I made the web3.eth.personal.unlockAccount and I was being able to deploy that contract). I was trying this: 

CrudAEOCreate.deployed().then(function(instance) { crud = instance;})

 crud.createMasterDataAEO(1234, "primerFuncRefNum1234", "primerDocName", "receipType", "receiptName", "senderType", "senderAEO", "12456" );

crud.associateMasterDataParty("primerFuncRefNum1234","PrimerpartyNameAEO","PrimerShortNameAEO","PrimerBusinessTypeAEO",2601,"Peru","PrimerRoleCodeAEO");

 crud.readAEO( "primerFuncRefNum1234","senderAEO","PrimerpartyNameAEO", 2601, "PrimerRoleCodeAEO");

And the two first don't give any error, but the third one gives the error of the image on the previous post.  The first two gave this outputs: 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21060405/57937231-e17f6f80-789b-11e9-8a26-a556c379ed82.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21060405/57937257-f0662200-789b-11e9-83ef-f6abd8b98d16.png)

On my contract, on the readAEO function, actually I need to have this on return: 
returns(string endDateAEO, string memory recipientAEO,
                                    string memory partyShortNameAEO, string memory businessTypeAEO, string memory identificationIssuingCountryAEO)

But with that statement, when I tried to call the function I got " returned values aren't valid, did it run out of gas?" so I try changing the return to an uint but anyway I am not being able to execute the function.
And also, do you know from where can I read what does each field of those outputs represent?

Thanks for the link!

>When I tried to compile it I got "stack too deep error"

This _might_ be resolved in the latest truffle release (5.0.18).

Regarding your `internal` functions, yes if you want them to return publicly something while on-chain then they need to be `public` (I'll take a look shortly to scope out your contracts functionality).

>But with that statement, when I tried to call the function I got " returned values aren't valid, did it run out of gas?"

I suspect this is because some of your transactions are private. I'll check it out.
Uh oh, is your repo private? It's showing up as not found.
Uh, it was private. Now I made it public , can you access?
Got it. Thanks! Will take a look in a bit 👍
Thank you!!
were you able to look in?

Hey @romisalve , the stack too deep error I ran into was `solc-js` specific:

```
truffle compile                 

Compiling your contracts...
===========================
> Compiling ./contracts/CrudAEOCreate.sol

/Users/cruzmolina/Code/truffle-projects/example/Quorum-POC/contracts/CrudAEOCreate.sol:207:22: CompilerError: Stack too deep, try removing local variables.
    if(addressExists[partyIdAEO]){
                     ^--------^

Compilation failed. See above.
Truffle (unbundled) (core: 5.0.18)
Node v11.4.0
```

I was able to comment out what appears to be redundant code and some unused variables to get it to work.
Just opened a PR on your repo, let me know if compilation works on your end 🤞

Also, regarding your `crud.readAEO` call in `truffle console`, if you notice in my PR, I commented out 3 unused parameters in the `readAEO` function definition. You were probably receiving the ` returned values aren't valid` error, because currently `readAEO` doesn't do anything with those 3 parameters.

If you test the code in my PR in the console and instead only pass something like `crud.readAEO( "primerFuncRefNum1234", "PrimerpartyNameAEO");`, you should receive appropriate output w/o an error.

@CruzMolina I am really thankful for your help and I have some questions if it is possible. 
I tried to deploy the contract with the changes of your PR but I am facing the error that contract code could not be stored, how can I solve this?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21060405/58103349-34696780-7bb9-11e9-9615-3184a5e345fc.png)

In the read function may I add the return statement with some string output parameters and some uints? 

Also, at the beginning of the contract I create some arrays and mappings. Originally, the contract was a CRUD contract but due to this same error, I decided to split it up into smaller contracts. What happen with those arrays and mapping created on the first contract if I need them for my operations on the other contracts? If I deploy all the contracts on my network, are they reachable from other contracts where they are not defined? Or which would be te approach?

And a final question, how can I expose my smart contract operations in order to consume them but no directly from truffle? I was planning to use Camunda BPM modeler to model some forms and consume smart contract methods. It is possible?

@romisalve What does your truffle config look like?

What worked on my end was:

```
module.exports = {
  networks: {
    nodeone: {
      host: "127.0.0.1",
      port: 22000,
      network_id: "*",
      gasPrice: 0,
      gas: 450000000,
      type: "quorum"
    }
  }
};
```

Also, if you could put up your entire truffle project in that repo, it would help me reproduce more easily.


example truffle project layout:
```
├── contracts
│   ├── CrudAEOCreate.sol
│   └── Migrations.sol
├── migrations
│   └── 1_initial_migration.js
├── test
└── truffle-config.js
```

>In the read function may I add the return statement with some string output parameters and some uints?

That should be fine. IIRC, the problem with the read calls you were making were directly related to your read function definition in the smart contract. The definition had multiple parameters that were completely unused or inaccessible. It looks like that's why web3 was throwing that "out of gas?" returned value err. I _think_ as long as you make sure whatever parameters are being passed are used in some manner within the function, you should be fine.

>What happen with those arrays and mapping created on the first contract if I need them for my operations on the other contracts? If I deploy all the contracts on my network, are they reachable from other contracts where they are not defined? Or which would be te approach?

Any mappings that are public can be read from another contract.  I believe if you want to add to those mappings, they either need to be added via a method in that contract, or through a contract you deploy that inherits that contract.

>And a final question, how can I expose my smart contract operations in order to consume them but no directly from truffle? I was planning to use Camunda BPM modeler to model some forms and consume smart contract methods. It is possible?

Oh, that's a really cool idea. You can probably use the Camunda BPM modeler with the contract json artifacts found after compilation in the `build` folder.

You might want to take a look at the abi spec (https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/tree/develop/packages/truffle-contract-schema#abi) since you're thinking specifically about contract methods. On that page you can also find the general contract json object schema although it needs to be updated since we now support NatSpec in Solidity contracts (https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/develop/natspec-format.html). Using NatSpec you can have `userdoc` and `devdoc` auto-populated into your contract build artifact. That might be a better higher level choice than using the abi. This documentation is a more up-to-date higher level look at how contract object json's get defined and written: https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/tree/develop/packages/truffle-artifactor#artifactorsavecontractdata

@CruzMolina 

> That should be fine. IIRC, the problem with the read calls you were making were directly related to your read function definition in the smart contract. The definition had multiple parameters that were completely unused or inaccessible. It looks like that's why web3 was throwing that "out of gas?" returned value err. I _think_ as long as you make sure whatever parameters are being passed are used in some manner within the function, you should be fine.

Thank you!! I'll have that in mind for every function.

> Any mappings that are public can be read from another contract. I believe if you want to add to those mappings, they either need to be added via a method in that contract, or through a contract you deploy that inherits that contract.

Ok, great. And to inherit a contract I need to define it as "_ contract nameOfTheContract is NameOfTheContractIWantToInheritFrom _ " and that is it? Then, to deploy them, in migrations directory I need to have a file for each contract or I can deploy them all thorugh the same migration file?


> Oh, that's a really cool idea. You can probably use the Camunda BPM modeler with the contract json artifacts found after compilation in the `build` folder.
> 
> You might want to take a look at the abi spec (https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/tree/develop/packages/truffle-contract-schema#abi) since you're thinking specifically about contract methods. On that page you can also find the general contract json object schema although it needs to be updated since we now support NatSpec in Solidity contracts (https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/develop/natspec-format.html). Using NatSpec you can have `userdoc` and `devdoc` auto-populated into your contract build artifact. That might be a better higher level choice than using the abi. This documentation is a more up-to-date higher level look at how contract object json's get defined and written: https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/tree/develop/packages/truffle-artifactor#artifactorsavecontractdata

Ok, so there is no way to have kind of an URL in order to hit it from POSTMAN for example and consume it services, isn´t it?  So I need to have like kind of a Java class for example from which I use the artifacts generated or how should it be done??

And in relation with this, If I am planning to have a network with four nodes. Do I need to have in each node that is going to interact with the network truffle installed?
